Name: Barium nitrate
Rationale for classification: Inorganic compounds containing oxygen and classified as powerful oxidants according to ICSC (2004). Classified as "Division 5.1: oxidizing substances" by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. However, it can be included in Category 2 or 3, given the fact that it has subsidiary risks corresponding to Division 6.1 and is assigned to Packing Group II (UN#1446). The substance is placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: cupric nitrate
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of UNRTDG Class: 5.1, PGII (N.O.S) and oxidizing solids (BGIA, GESTIS-database on hazardous substancess, Accessed in June 2006)

Name: Lead dinitrate
Rationale for classification: Inorganic compounds containing oxygen which "intensifies combustion of other materials" according to ICSC (2004). Classified as "Division 5.1: oxidizing substances" by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. However, it can be included in Category 2 or 3, given the fact that it has subsidiary risks corresponding to Division 6.1 and is assigned to Packing Group II (UN#1469). The substance is placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Thallium nitrate
Rationale for classification: Inorganic compounds containing oxygen and classified as a powerful oxidant according to HSDB (2006). Classified as "Division 5.1: oxidizing substances" by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. However, it can be included in Category 2 or 3, given the fact that it has subsidiary risks corresponding to Division 6.1 and is assigned to Packing Group II (UN#2727). The substance is placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: hydrogen peroxide--urea
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG No. 1511, Class: 5.1(8); PG III.

Name: barium peroxide
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG No. 1449, Class: 5.1; PG II.

Name: Lead dioxide
Rationale for classification: Inorganic compounds containing oxygen which "intensifies combustion of other materials" according to ICSC (2004). Classified into Division 5.1, Packing Group III (UN#1872) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

Name: disodium peroxide
Hazard statement: May cause fire or explosion; strong oxidizer
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG No. 1504, Class: 5.1; PG I.

Name: Nickel dinitrate
Rationale for classification: Inorganic compounds containing oxygen, which may cause fire when in contact with wood or paper (HSDB (2006)). Classified into Division 5.1 (UN#2725) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

Name: Sodium decylbenzenesulfonate (C10)
Classification: Oxidizing solids - Classification not possible (as a solid)
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to elements other than carbon and hydrogen

Name: Ammonium dodecylbenzenesulphonate (C12)
Classification: Oxidizing solids - Classification not possible (as a solid)
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to elements other than carbon and hydrogen

Name: Chromium trioxide
Rationale for classification: Classified as "Division 5.1: oxidizing substances" by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. It can, however, be included in Category 2 or 3, given the fact that it has subsidiary risks corresponding to Division 6.1 and Class 8 and is assigned to Packing Group II (UN#1493). The substance is placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Carbon black
Classification: Oxidizing solids - Not applicable(Materials of animal or vegetable origin and mineral origin)
Rationale for classification: Containing no oxygen , chlorine and fluorine.

Name: barium chlorate
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG No. 1445, Class: 5.1(6.1); PG II.
